description: From Middle English seekly, sekely, siklich, sekeliche, equivalent to sick +‎ -ly. Possibly a modification of Old English sīcle (“sickly”) and/or derived from Old Norse sjúkligr (“sickly”). Cognate with Dutch ziekelijk, Middle High German siechlich, Danish sygelig, Swedish sjuklig, Icelandic sjúklegur.

entries.meaning: Frequently ill or in poor health.

examples: The season was dreary, I was sickly, and found the friends sickly whom I went to see.

entries.meaning: (of a plant) Characterized by poor or unhealthy growth.
examples: [...] the good wheat on this land had turned sickly and yellow.

entries.meaning: Appearing ill, infirm or unhealthy; giving the appearance of illness.
Shedding a relatively small amount of light; (of light) not very bright.
Associated with poor moral or mental well-being.
(obsolete) Marked by the occurrence of illness or disease (of a period of time).
examples: [...] if I thought the sentiments of your last letter were not the sentiments of a sickly moment—if I could be made to believe, for an instant, that they proceeded from you, in a sober, reflecting condition of your mind—I should give you over as incurable,

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Tending to produce disease or poor health.
examples: a sickly autumn; a sickly climate

adverbs.description: sickly (comparative more sickly, superlative most sickly)

entries.meaning: In a sick manner; in a way that reflects or causes sickness.

verbs.description: sickly (third-person singular simple present sicklies, present participle sicklying, simple past and past participle sicklied)

examples: Thy Drudge contrives, and in our full career
Sicklies our hopes with the pale hue of Fear;
But the seven most prominent Apostles  […]  still hang together, their hearts tormented with eager yet sad questionings, their hopes fast sicklying over with the pale hues of doubt.
